chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Knowledge and the Renunciation of Action
sanskrit:
अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति।
नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः॥
transliteration:
ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca saṁśayātmā vinaśyati |
nāyaṁ loko'sti na para na sukhaṁ saṁśayātmanaḥ ||
translation: The ignorant, the faithless, and the doubting self perishes. For the doubting soul, there is neither this world, nor the next, nor any happiness.
commentary:
This verse presents a stark warning about the destructive nature of doubt and lack of faith in spiritual matters. Krishna identifies three types of unfortunate individuals: the ignorant (ajña) who lack knowledge, the faithless (aśraddadhāna) who lack conviction even when knowledge is available, and the doubting (saṁśayātmā) who are perpetually skeptical. Among these, the doubting nature is particularly emphasized as most detrimental, as doubt paralyzes all spiritual progress and prevents one from taking any decisive action toward self-realization.

The verse concludes with a powerful statement about the fate of those consumed by doubt. Such individuals find no peace or fulfillment in this world (ayaṁ loka), as they cannot commit to worldly pursuits with full conviction. They also forfeit the next world (para loka), as their doubt prevents them from following spiritual practices sincerely. Most significantly, they are denied happiness (sukha) altogether, as happiness requires either full engagement with the world or complete spiritual dedication—both of which are impossible for the doubting mind. This verse serves as a culmination of Krishna's teaching on jñāna-yoga in this chapter, emphasizing that faith (śraddhā) and conviction are essential prerequisites for spiritual knowledge to bear fruit.
speaker: Krishna
